node.title: Professional Solution Architecture from an Amateur Game Developer | Out the Door Devlog
node.description:
A pinch of planning is worth a pound of effort! DW uses his day job skills as a solution architect to diagram not one, not two, but THREE WHOLE system controllers! These diagrams are more than just pretty pictures, but are also plans on how the in-game systems will record the player’s action to power the game rules and build the game state for Out the Door. 

Play the OUT-THE-DOOR Prototype Today! (Web & Windows)
|-- https://davidwesst.itch.io/out-the-door
|-- https://ldjam.com/events/ludum-dare/47/out-the-door

–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– 
Resource & Links 
–––––––––––––––––––––––––––––– 

Front Controller Pattern 
|-- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Front_controller

node.title: I forgot the most important part of my game | Out The Door Devlog
node.description:
I'm delaying the 0.5 release of Out The Door. Why? It's not because of schedule, but because I forgot the most fundamental part of any game: The gameplay. Fear not though! When life gives you lemons, you give 'em back....or make lemonade in my case. 😋

Play (the old) OUT-THE-DOOR Today! (Windows)
|- https://davidwesst.itch.io/out-the-door
|- https://ldjam.com/events/ludum-dare/47/out-the-door

node.title: Solo Gamejam Experience | A Ludum Dare 47 Story
node.description:
DW goes over the the experience being an amateur gamedev doing a gamejam...solo. 

What does it take to enter a gamejam? After submitting Out the Door to Ludum Dare 47, DW discusses the why, how, and what with respect to participating in a 3-day gamejam as an amateur with a full-time non-game development, along with a family, and a household to maintain (all during a pandemic).

Play OUT-THE-DOOR Today! (Web & Windows)
|- https://davidwesst.itch.io/out-the-door
|- https://ldjam.com/events/ludum-dare/47/out-the-door

node.title: Developer Art Stream | LDJam 47 Prep
node.description:
DW steps outside his comfort zone and attempt to create and integrate custom pixel art into a Godot project in preparation for Ludum Dare 47.

DW's current objectives (which he manages to achieve...sort of)

- Build basic level in Tiled from custom Aseprite art
- Draw minimal player animation in Aseprite
- Export/Import into Tiled
- Import character and/or level into Godot

node.title: GDevelop, Prototyping, and Noobness | Stream Highlights
node.description:
Highlights from the 2-Hour Tech Spike that disappointed DW.

As promised, DW completed a 2-Hour Tech Spike for GDevelop where he attempted to setup the scaffold and prototype a new game idea called Out the Door. Unfortunately, it goes sideways right away as DW assumed tilemap support either in-engine or as an import using TMX files from Tiled. It only gets worse as he trips up on getting controller input working and can't seem to figure out why the left direction on the left control stick doesn't work.

You can see the original full stream here: https://youtu.be/YQNHP53luKI

00:00 Start
00:15 Intro
01:11 The Plan
03:05 Not Finding Tilemap Support
06:31 Starting on Controller Support
08:09 Finally seeing/understanding Behaviours
08:59 Frustration!
09:18 Brain Dump (i.e. Raw Concluding Thoughts)
12:53 Conclusion

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Links & Resources
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

GDevelop - https://gdevelop-app.com/
Kitchen and More Assets - https://limezu.itch.io/kitchen
Tiled Map Editor - https://thorbjorn.itch.io/tiled

--------------------------------------------------------------------------

node.title: GDevelop, Prototyping, and Noobness | 2-Hour Tech Spike LIVE
node.description:
TL;DR; -- Checkout the highlights here: https://youtu.be/rRmmIqjdq2U

This is it friendos-- I am _actually_ going to attempt to use GDevelop and understand the tool. No tricks, no quitting, no other IDE. Just me, a game idea to prototype, and my interest in this JavaScript game development toolset.

Here's the plan (which is subject to change):

Quick Recap of the last two GDevelop experiences
Tech Spike GO!
    - Make something move with controller and/or mouse (i.e. Object with Behaviours and Input Extensions)
    - Create a map to move around (i.e. Collision Extension)
    - Dialogue System for displaying informational text (i.e. Dialogue Extension)
    - Export to Web/Windows
Recap & Retrospective

--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Links & Resources
--------------------------------------------------------------------------

GDevelop - https://gdevelop-app.com/
Kitchen and More Assets - https://limezu.itch.io/kitchen
Tiled Map Editor - https://thorbjorn.itch.io/tiled

node.title: Games as Overlays | 2-Hour Tech Spike LIVE
node.description:
Original Title: Exploring GDevelop (Attempt #2)

In this comeback livestream, DW attempts to build a "game" out of GDevelop that can be an overlay in OBS Studio...but ends up hitting a technical snag early on and abandons ship to build the whole idea in Godot 3.2.2 quickly.

node.title: Developer Art & Collaboration | A Ludum Dare 46 Devlog
node.description:
DW documents his surprise gamejam entry, as suggested by his friend D'Arcy Lussier, where they produce a playable game now known as Little Shop of Wall Street.

In this video, we cover the process of being in a gamejam as an amateur game developer, equipped with only your side project experience. We cover the how the concept came about, the importance of getting out of your skillset comfort zone, all delivered through progress updates that were recorded nightly over the weekend.

Follow-up LIVESTREAM on Wednesday, April 22, 2020 - https://youtu.be/mnhcnBJoPo0

01:24 Night 0 - Engine
02:28 Night 0 - Theme
03:39 Night 1 - Concept
04:29 Night 1 - Game Loop
06:21 Night 1 - Code
08:16 Night 2 - Song
09:00 Night 2 - Art
09:59 Night 2 - Demo
11:11 Night 3 - Demo
14:50 Conclusion

node.title: Ludum Dare 46 Post-Mortem
node.description:
I received an invitation to attempt to make time to participate in a couple of game jams over the next couple of weeks. My thought is to use a full-fledged non-coding tool that publishes to the web natively for some lightweight prototypes.

Going to take a look and compare them to Unity and Godot (which I consider much heavier). 

With Ludum Dare 46 complete, DW debriefs with his collaborator, D'Arcy Lussier, to talk about their experience with the jam, the tools, the process, and what is next for the Little Shop of Wall Street.

03:09 - First Time Gamejam Thoughts from D'Arcy
07:30 - Tooling
09:06 - Waiting for Go-Dot?
10:56 - Line of Business Devs as Gamedevs
15:36 - Streamers Troll the Chat 
16:56 - Godot as a first-timer gamedev
19:22 - Transferable LOB Skills for Gamedevs
24:14 - Value of Constraints
27:51 - Importance of a Web-Based Version
30:46 - Next Steps for Little Shop of Wall Street
40:41 - Chat Tells Pirate Jokes
41:15 - Ludum Dare 47 & Team Dads + RCI (Non-Dev Team Member)
44:38 - Closing Thoughts & Takeaways from LD46

node.title: From Godot to Unity to Writing Tests Too Late | March 2020 Devlog
node.description:
Another month, albeit pretty crazy, but still another bunch of game development progress for March 2020.

This month, I get into the code by doing a C# experiment with Godot, migrate the project over to Unity (i.e. Unity3D), write some complex logic without tests, discover the complex logic is flawed and start writing tests while refactoring.

Also, I started livestreaming and you can (hopefully) expect to see more of that next month.

GitHub Issue: https://github.com/giulianob/SampleGodotProject/issues/2

node.description:
In this video, DW goes through five things he's been using in GitHub while designing his latest prototype that require zero coding skills. 

GitHub is a social development platform that will make your game development journey easier even if you're not a coder! We'll cover how GitHub can help keep your file history, through to how it can help organize your work, and even where to find cool projects to learn (and possibly contribute to).

node.title: January 2020 Devlog | Car Scientist Web Version and Game Breaking Bug Fixes
node.description:
Did you know that I really try and make video games and not just talk about them? Me neither, but this video will fix all that!

I tend to fall into the crutch of talking about technology rather than actually doing it. There is nothing wrong with the evangelism/marketing side of the tech community, but the whole point of me doing this is to share my journey and the tips along the way. Note the "journey" part means, I have to move the needle. An so, here we are with the first devlog of the year. 

In this video I cover the bit of progres I've had on Car Scientist, and how it's become something of a game development sandbox to practice and (ideally) sharpen my gamedev skills. I also review the LARGE amount of planning I did and reflect a bit on how I sort through what ideas should be in this game versus the next one.

#devlog #carscientist #myfirstgamejam #gamedev #gamedesign #gamedevelopment #gamedeveloper #community #technology #techcommunity #usergroup #chat #professionaldevelopment #itchio #web #html5 #godot

🎮 The Game

node.title: Where to find your GameDev Community (and to tell if they're any good)
node.description:
Four places to find your new game development and/or design community and figure out if it's even good!

Did you know there are people out there who will help you with your game because they WANT TO DO IT? I know, right? This magical place is called a “community” and they exist literally all over the world. You just need to find one. In this video, I talk about four different places to find technology and game development/design communities right from where your sitting.

node.title: No Cost Game Design Toolbox and Process
node.description:
Want to design games but have no money? Never fear, for my game design toolbox (and process) can help get you started!

I've spent the past week working on the the game design for #CarScientist. What I noticed was that I didn't open a code editor or development tool once this whole week, and considering that's my comfort zone when it comes to any form of software development, I was both surprised and pleased that I managed to wear my design hat so well!

On top of just being in design mode, I avoided my other "excuse" which is to want and research what you don't have, which is usually some tool or domain I think is clever. This whole toolbox not only keeps me focused, but it keeps me on budget as well as you can get all of it for nothing. Take a look and let me know in the comments your thoughts on my game design toolbox, along with what tools you use.

#Conquest #Devlog #CarScientist #GameDevelopment #GameDev #GameDesign #VagabondGame #GameDesignTools #ProTips #DesignProcess #VideoGameDevelopment #VideoGameDesign

node.title: Day 30 Devlog - Victory! I am a Gamedev!
node.description:
Achievement Unlocked! Car Scientist is submitted to the #GitHubGameOff game jam!
Play the game at https://davidwesst.itch.io/leaps-and-bounds

I bring you the game: Car Scientist! The game jam is complete and my game is submitted for review. Best game ever? No. Will it will all the awards? Probably not. Did I accomplish something I had never accomplished before? Abso-freaking-lutely! 

In this video, I take some time to brain dump my initial feelings now that the game jam is complete. Where it's been, where it's going, along with the pitfalls and possibilities of the game are all for another day. For now, I'm going to soak in the accomplishment and enjoy my evening.

node.title: Day 26 | Dialogue and Self Doubt
node.description:
After two days of writing dialogue and game logic I am starting to feel some imposter syndrome coming on.
Join my gamedev journey at https://d.wes.st/itchio

After being neck deep in dialogue and game logic code (two things that are very new to me) and as the deadline approaches, I have started to feel imposter syndrome and my mind is filling with self-doubt. At this point, it would be easy to make up an excuse for why I can't finish the game, but I AM NOT GOING TO DO THAT! In this vlog, I briefly discuss my feelings as I "fake it 'til I make it" and the editor tool I use for dialogue writing, Inky.

References
Inky - https://github.com/inkle/inky

node.title: Day 12-13 Devlog | New Tool Lemonade
node.description:
New toolset giving you lemons? Then realize that it's really pooly timed lemonade! 
Join my gamedev journey and follow the project at https://d.wes.st/itchio

After banging my head against the keyboard last night and tonight, I finally realized that the problem was that I was looking too deep for the answer to my dialogue box display issues. Although this be frustrating now, at the end of the day this allowed me to learn more about the Godot engine that I decided to use for this project. Being an old software developer, I know that this exploration is necessary-- even if it's untimely.

node.description:
Minimized the scope, recorded some gameplay, and feeling good about Godot!

node.title: Day 0 Devlog | Announcing my Participation in Game Off 2019 After Wasting 3 Hours
node.description:
Day 0. Took me three hours to announce my participation in the Game Off game jam.
Find me and the project! https://d.wes.st/itchio

I wanted to make a little announcement vlog post about my participation in the Game Off Game Jam hosted by GitHub on Itch.io...but instead I fell into my old habits and started making a polished up video. After three hours and _still_ not being done, I decided to call it quits.

Then I got frustrated. Then I got angry. Then I got out of bed and made this video. It's not my best work, but more (and importantly) -- IT'S DONE! 

More to talk about next time. Stay strong, stay focused, and mind the door.

––––––––––––––––––––––––––––––
Find me on the Internets!
